description:
This PR implements a new command, "yt search".  This will recurse through a
list of subdirectories and attempt to identify any outputs that can be loaded
by yt.  This list should be considered to be overlapping, but not strictly a
superset or subset of, the total possible output files.

It is not complete yet.  Currently, FLASH, FITS and Enzo are supported.  I can see easy roads for a bunch of other dataset types.

What I would like to do is to implement a simple *indexing* system, as well.
This indexing system would output to a JSON file a catalog of datasets that yt
finds inside a given subdirectory.  This will be controllable by a command line
argument.

Ideally, what this will enable us to do is the following:

 * Output some set of characteristics of a file.  This needs to be decided upon, and is why I think of this as an RFC.  What characteristics are there for a given dataset that would be useful to store in a simple format?
 * Output to a specificable filename.
 * Load data as specified in a .json file.  For instance, I should be able to index my directories, then load with some shorthand, or at least print out a list of indexed files from within yt.

As it stands, this won't be useful to go in until we decide on the minimum
representation of the data that we want in the json files.  Thoughts,
particularly @brittonsmith @ngoldbaum @jzuhone @xarthisius ?

UPDATE 1:

This now includes some minor changes and adds support for FITS to the search command.  I think it is ready to go in, if people are generally okay with it.  @jzuhone can you look over the FITS changes?

Once this is in, I am going to construct a second pull request that will enable using tinydb for querying known datasets.  Right now this outputs all of the data that folks suggested, and also enables outputting the contents of the `.parameters` attribute (optionally).
title: yt search command

content.raw: Isn't it going to be extremely difficult to search for datafiles from certain frontends (e.g. ones that arbitrary filename extensions)?  Maybe I'm missing something here and the search isn't just based on filenames that it finds.
content.html: Isn't it going to be extremely difficult to search for datafiles from certain frontends (e.g. ones that arbitrary filename extensions)? Maybe I'm missing something here and the search isn't just based on filenames that it finds.

content.raw: Potential "characteristics" of datasets to search/filter for:  frontend, final redshift, gridsize (or resolution somehow).
content.html: Potential "characteristics" of datasets to search/filter for: frontend, final redshift, gridsize (or resolution somehow).

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/944/

I won't be fixing these style checks until the PR is ready to go in.
Despite the fact that they are reported as "unittest" failures, they are in
fact style checks, *not* real failures.
content.html: I won't be fixing these style checks until the PR is ready to go in. Despite the fact that they are reported as "unittest" failures, they are in fact style checks, not real failures.

content.raw: Huh, that sure was grumpy.  I am sorry for the harshness of that reply to the test results!  Nathan let me know how to mark things as not being problematic, so I'll be doing that (if they aren't fixed) in the next update and the style failures won't happen.
content.html: Huh, that sure was grumpy. I am sorry for the harshness of that reply to the test results! Nathan let me know how to mark things as not being problematic, so I'll be doing that (if they aren't fixed) in the next update and the style failures won't happen.

content.raw:
It is going to be difficult, but there are three mitigating factors:

 * We don't need to catch everything; explicitly, we will note this in the `search` help.  This is just an estimate of possibilities.
 * Candidates do not need to be actual datasets, as they can just be candidates
 * The filtering currently is implemented as just being based on filenames, but it could theoretically be based on non-filename attributes.  I think this is unlikely to be a good idea, though, since it will require a first filename based pass to avoid 100% IO overhead, which is the point of having "candidate" instead of "actual".
content.html:
It is going to be difficult, but there are three mitigating factors:

  • We don't need to catch everything; explicitly, we will note this in the search help. This is just an estimate of possibilities.
  • Candidates do not need to be actual datasets, as they can just be candidates
  • The filtering currently is implemented as just being based on filenames, but it could theoretically be based on non-filename attributes. I think this is unlikely to be a good idea, though, since it will require a first filename based pass to avoid 100% IO overhead, which is the point of having "candidate" instead of "actual".

content.raw: Maybe we could make style tests a separate test subset not filed under unittests, so it is clearer when a test failure is not due to code breakages.  Obviously not for this PR, but just an idea.
content.html: Maybe we could make style tests a separate test subset not filed under unittests, so it is clearer when a test failure is not due to code breakages. Obviously not for this PR, but just an idea.

content.raw: I'd really love to have something like that. Especially because it could be plugged into girder as automatic metadata extractor. I wouldn't worry about IO bottlenecks right now. First implementation should *just* work, we can optimize it later if necessary.
content.html: I'd really love to have something like that. Especially because it could be plugged into girder as automatic metadata extractor. I wouldn't worry about IO bottlenecks right now. First implementation should just work, we can optimize it later if necessary.

content.raw: For resolution studies, I think it'd be useful to filter on both domain_dimension and number of AMR levels (on AMR datasets).
content.html: For resolution studies, I think it'd be useful to filter on both domain_dimension and number of AMR levels (on AMR datasets).

content.raw:
I've updated this PR, including comments from here and from @mzingale and @ngoldbaum.  This now takes options `-f` and `-a`, which will output the full parameter set and also check every file.  (For me this breaks sometimes, especially on things like `ATOMIC.DAT` that it found in my data directory.)  If you use `-f` note that the Enzo parameter files will make your `yt_index.json` lots bigger.

Following this, I'm going to explore using [tinydb](http://tinydb.readthedocs.org/en/latest/) to query them, if it's installed.
content.html:
I've updated this PR, including comments from here and from Michael Zingale and Nathan Goldbaum. This now takes options -f and -a, which will output the full parameter set and also check every file. (For me this breaks sometimes, especially on things like ATOMIC.DAT that it found in my data directory.) If you use -f note that the Enzo parameter files will make your yt_index.json lots bigger.

Following this, I'm going to explore using tinydb to query them, if it's installed.
